- USER: - Task Description: Complete the java class for the following code: 
```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
		//        throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		// TODO student implementation
		return new Move[0];
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

```. The task parameters are:
- Class name: Archer
- BOT: 
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getCols();

		int srcRow = source.getRow();
		int srcCol = source.getCol();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPieceAt(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

Response Text:---
The compilation errors indicate that the methods `getRows()`, `getCols()` in `Configuration`, `getRow()`, `getCol()` in `Place`, and `getPieceAt(Place)` in `Game` do not exist or are named differently in your project API.

You need to use the correct method names according to your project's API. Common alternatives are:

- For board size: `getNumRows()`, `getNumCols()` or `getHeight()`, `getWidth()`
- For Place coordinates: `row()`, `col()` (record-style getter), or `getX()`, `getY()`
- For getting piece at a place: possibly `getPiece(Place)` instead of `getPieceAt(Place)`

Assuming your `Place` class uses record-style accessors (`row()`, `col()`), `Configuration` uses `getNumRows()`, `getNumCols()`, and `Game` uses `getPiece(Place)`, here is the corrected class:

```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getNumRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getNumCols();

		int srcRow = source.row();
		int srcCol = source.col();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPiece(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}
```

This should fix the compilation errors by using the correct method names for your API.

Response Code:---

package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getNumRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getNumCols();

		int srcRow = source.row();
		int srcCol = source.col();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPiece(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getNumRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getNumCols();

		int srcRow = source.row();
		int srcCol = source.col();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPiece(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}

- USER: - Task Description: Complete the java class for the following code: 
```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
		//        throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		// TODO student implementation
		return new Move[0];
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

```. The task parameters are:
- Class name: Archer
- BOT: 
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getCols();

		int srcRow = source.getRow();
		int srcCol = source.getCol();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPieceAt(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getNumRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getNumCols();

		int srcRow = source.row();
		int srcCol = source.col();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPiece(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

Response Text:---
The errors indicate that the methods to get board dimensions are not named `getNumRows()` or `getNumCols()`, and that `Place` does not have `row()` or `col()` methods (likely it uses `getRow()` and `getCol()` instead). Also, the method to get a piece at a place is probably `getPieceAt(Place)` as originally used.

Here is the corrected class using `getRow()`, `getCol()`, `getRows()`, `getCols()`, and `getPieceAt()` methods consistently:

```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getCols();

		int srcRow = source.getRow();
		int srcCol = source.getCol();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPieceAt(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}
```

**Explanation:**  
- Used `getRows()` and `getCols()` for board dimensions as indicated by the original error.  
- Used `getRow()` and `getCol()` for `Place` accessors (likely standard getter methods).  
- Used `game.getPieceAt(Place)` to get the piece at a location, matching original method names.  

This should fix the compilation errors.
---Response Text

Response Code:---

package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getCols();

		int srcRow = source.getRow();
		int srcCol = source.getCol();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPieceAt(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}
---Response Code
- BOT: 
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getCols();

		int srcRow = source.getRow();
		int srcCol = source.getCol();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPieceAt(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}

```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
		//        throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		// TODO student implementation
		return new Move[0];
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

- BOT: 
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getCols();

		int srcRow = source.getRow();
		int srcCol = source.getCol();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPieceAt(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getNumRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getNumCols();

		int srcRow = source.row();
		int srcCol = source.col();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPiece(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().getRows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().getCols();

		int srcRow = source.getRow();
		int srcCol = source.getCol();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPieceAt(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPieceAt(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

Response Text:---
The compilation errors indicate that the methods `getRows()`, `getCols()`, `getRow()`, `getCol()`, and `getPieceAt()` do not exist in the respective classes. Instead, the correct methods are likely named `rows()`, `cols()`, and the fields in `Place` are accessed directly (likely as public final fields or via record components), and the method to get a piece from the game is probably `getPiece(Place)`.

Here is the corrected complete class using these assumptions:

```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().rows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().cols();

		int srcRow = source.row();
		int srcCol = source.col();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPiece(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}
```

**Explanation:**  
- Changed `getRows()` and `getCols()` to `rows()` and `cols()` as per the likely method names in `Configuration`.  
- Changed `source.getRow()` and `source.getCol()` to `source.row()` and `source.col()` assuming `Place` is a record or has these accessor methods.  
- Changed `game.getPieceAt(Place)` to `game.getPiece(Place)` as the method to get a piece at a place.  

This should fix the compilation errors.
---Response Text

Response Code:---

package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Piece;
import assignment.protocol.Place;
import assignment.protocol.Player;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).
 *
 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */
public class Archer extends Piece {
	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.
	 * Given the {@link Game} object and the {@link Place} that current knight piece locates, this method should
	 * return ALL VALID {@link Move}s according to the current {@link Place} of this knight piece.
	 * All the returned {@link Move} should have source equal to the source parameter.
	 * <p>
	 * Hint: you should consider corner cases when the {@link Move} is not valid on the gameboard.
	 * Several tests are provided and your implementation should pass them.
	 * <p>
	 * <strong>Attention: Student should make sure all {@link Move}s returned are valid.</strong>
	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */
	@Override
	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {
		List<Move> moves = new ArrayList<>();
		int rows = game.getConfiguration().rows();
		int cols = game.getConfiguration().cols();

		int srcRow = source.row();
		int srcCol = source.col();

		// Directions: up, down, left, right
		int[][] directions = {
			{-1, 0}, // up
			{1, 0},  // down
			{0, -1}, // left
			{0, 1}   // right
		};

		for (int[] dir : directions) {
			int dRow = dir[0];
			int dCol = dir[1];

			// Step 1: Move along direction through empty squares (vacant moves)
			int r = srcRow + dRow;
			int c = srcCol + dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square, can move here
					Move move = new Move(source, dest);
					if (validateMove(game, move)) {
						moves.add(move);
					}
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
				} else {
					// Found the screen piece, break to step 2
					break;
				}
			}

			// Step 2: Find the screen piece (must be exactly one piece between source and target)
			// If no screen piece found, no capture moves in this direction
			if (r < 0 || r >= rows || c < 0 || c >= cols) {
				// Out of boundary, no screen piece
				continue;
			}
			Place screenPlace = new Place(r, c);
			Piece screenPiece = game.getPiece(screenPlace);
			if (screenPiece == null) {
				// No screen piece, no capture moves
				continue;
			}

			// Step 3: After screen piece, move forward to find capture target (must be opponent piece)
			r += dRow;
			c += dCol;
			while (r >= 0 && r < rows && c >= 0 && c < cols) {
				Place dest = new Place(r, c);
				Piece p = game.getPiece(dest);
				if (p == null) {
					// Empty square after screen piece, cannon cannot move here
					r += dRow;
					c += dCol;
					continue;
				} else {
					// Found a piece after screen piece
					if (!p.getPlayer().equals(this.getPlayer())) {
						// Opponent piece can be captured
						Move move = new Move(source, dest);
						if (validateMove(game, move)) {
							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

	private boolean validateMove(Game game, Move move) {
		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),
				new FirstNMovesProtectionRule(game.getConfiguration().getNumMovesProtection()), new ArcherMoveRule(), };
		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}
}

import assignment.protocol.Move;

import java.util.List;

/**
 * Archer piece that moves similar to cannon in chinese chess.
 * Rules of move of Archer can be found in wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon).

 * @see <a href='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiangqi#Cannon'>Wikipedia</a>
 */

	public Archer(Player player) {
		super(player);
	}

	@Override
	public char getLabel() {
		return 'A';
	}

	/**
	 * Returns an array of moves that are valid given the current place of the piece.

	 *
	 * @param game   the game object
	 * @param source the current place of the piece
	 * @return an array of available moves
	 */

	public Move[] getAvailableMoves(Game game, Place source) {

		int cols = game.getConfiguration().cols();

		};

							moves.add(move);
						}
					}
					// Whether capture or not, stop searching further in this direction
					break;
				}
			}
		}

		return moves.toArray(Move[]::new);
	}

		var rules = new Rule[] { new OutOfBoundaryRule(), new OccupiedRule(), new VacantRule(), new NilMoveRule(),

		for (var rule : rules) {
			if (!rule.validate(game, move)) {
				return false;
			}
		}
		return true;
	}

Response Text:---
The `FirstNMovesProtectionRule` class enforces a rule that disallows capturing moves within the first `numProtectedMoves` moves of the game. To complete the `validate` method, we need to check if the current move is a capturing move and if the number of moves played so far is less than `numProtectedMoves`. If both conditions are true, the move is invalid.

Here is the completed class with the `validate` method properly implemented:

```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;

/**
 * The rule that requires capturing piece is not allowed within the first certain number of moves.
 */
public class FirstNMovesProtectionRule implements Rule {
	/**
	 * The number of moves within which capturing piece is not allowed.
	 */
	private final int numProtectedMoves;

	public FirstNMovesProtectionRule(int numProtectedMoves) {
		this.numProtectedMoves = numProtectedMoves;
	}

	@Override
	public boolean validate(Game game, Move move) {
		// Check if the move is a capturing move and if the number of moves played so far is less than numProtectedMoves
		if (move.isCapture() && game.getMoveCount() < numProtectedMoves) {
			return false;
		}
		return true;
	}

	@Override
	public String getDescription() {
		return "Capturing piece in the first " + this.numProtectedMoves + " moves are not allowed";
	}
}
```

This implementation assumes that `Move` has a method `isCapture()` to determine if the move captures a piece, and `Game` has a method `getMoveCount()` returning the number of moves played so far.

import assignment.protocol.Move;

Response Text:---
The compilation errors indicate that the `Move` class does not have an `isCapture()` method and the `Game` class does not have a `getMoveCount()` method. To fix this, you need to use the correct methods or properties available in these classes to determine if a move is a capture and to get the number of moves played so far.

Assuming typical naming conventions and common design in such game protocols, you might have to check if the move's target position is occupied by an opponent's piece to determine a capture, and the game might provide a method like `getNumberOfMoves()` or similar to get the move count.

Since I don't have the exact API of `Game` and `Move`, I will assume the following:
- `Move` has a method `isCaptureMove()` or a way to check if the move captures a piece, for example, `getCapturedPiece()` returning null if no capture.
- `Game` has a method `getNumberOfMoves()` or `getMovesPlayed()` returning an int.

If these assumptions are incorrect, you should adjust the method names accordingly.

Here is a corrected version that uses a generic approach: it checks if the move captures by checking if `move.getCapturedPiece()` is not null, and gets the move count by `game.getNumberOfMoves()`.

```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;

/**
 * The rule that requires capturing piece is not allowed within the first certain number of moves.
 */
public class FirstNMovesProtectionRule implements Rule {
	/**
	 * The number of moves within which capturing piece is not allowed.
	 */
	private final int numProtectedMoves;

	public FirstNMovesProtectionRule(int numProtectedMoves) {
		this.numProtectedMoves = numProtectedMoves;
	}

	@Override
	public boolean validate(Game game, Move move) {
		// Check if the move is a capturing move and if the number of moves played so far is less than numProtectedMoves
		if (move.getCapturedPiece() != null && game.getNumberOfMoves() < numProtectedMoves) {
			return false;
		}
		return true;
	}

	@Override
	public String getDescription() {
		return "Capturing piece in the first " + this.numProtectedMoves + " moves are not allowed";
	}
}
```

If `getCapturedPiece()` or `getNumberOfMoves()` do not exist, please provide the API or method signatures of `Game` and `Move` so I can tailor the solution exactly.

 * The rule that requires capturing piece is not allowed within the first certain number of moves.

	 * The number of moves within which capturing piece is not allowed.

Response Text:---
The compilation errors indicate that the methods `getCapturedPiece()` in `Move` and `getNumberOfMoves()` in `Game` do not exist. You need to use the correct methods provided by these interfaces/classes. Since the exact API is unknown, a common approach is:

- For `Move`, check if the move is a capture by comparing the destination square's occupant or by a method like `isCapture()` or `getCaptured()` if available. Since those are not available, assume `Move` has a method `getCapturedPosition()` or `getCapturedPiecePosition()` or a method `captures()` returning a boolean. If none exist, check if the move's captured piece is represented by `move.getCaptured()` or `move.getCapturedPiece()` or `move.getCapture()`.

- For `Game`, the number of moves played might be accessible by `game.getMoves().size()` or `game.getMoveHistory().size()` or `game.getTurnCount()`.

Since the previous attempts failed, let's assume:

- `Move` has a method `captures()` returning boolean indicating if the move captures a piece.

- `Game` has a method `getTurnCount()` returning the number of moves played so far.

If these methods do not exist, you must adapt accordingly, but this is the most reasonable guess.

---

```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;

/**
 * The rule that requires capturing piece is not allowed within the first certain number of moves.
 */
public class FirstNMovesProtectionRule implements Rule {
    /**
     * The number of moves within which capturing piece is not allowed.
     */
    private final int numProtectedMoves;

    public FirstNMovesProtectionRule(int numProtectedMoves) {
        this.numProtectedMoves = numProtectedMoves;
    }

    @Override
    public boolean validate(Game game, Move move) {
        // If the move captures a piece and the number of moves played so far is less than numProtectedMoves, disallow it
        if (move.captures() && game.getTurnCount() < numProtectedMoves) {
            return false;
        }
        return true;
    }

    @Override
    public String getDescription() {
        return "Capturing piece in the first " + this.numProtectedMoves + " moves are not allowed";
    }
}
```

Response Text:---
The compilation errors indicate that the methods `captures()` on `Move` and `getTurnCount()` on `Game` do not exist. You need to use the correct methods provided by the `Move` and `Game` interfaces/classes in your project. Since the exact method names are unknown, a common approach is to check if the move's target position is occupied by an opponent's piece (indicating a capture), and to get the number of moves or turns played so far, the method might be named something like `getMovesPlayed()` or `getMoveNumber()`.

Assuming the `Move` class has a method `getCaptured()` returning the captured piece or `null` if none, and `Game` has a method `getMovesPlayed()` returning the number of moves played so far, the following implementation should work.

If these assumptions are incorrect, you should verify the actual method names in your `Game` and `Move` classes.

Here is the corrected class using these assumptions:

```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;

/**
 * The rule that requires capturing piece is not allowed within the first certain number of moves.
 */
public class FirstNMovesProtectionRule implements Rule {
    /**
     * The number of moves within which capturing piece is not allowed.
     */
    private final int numProtectedMoves;

    public FirstNMovesProtectionRule(int numProtectedMoves) {
        this.numProtectedMoves = numProtectedMoves;
    }

    @Override
    public boolean validate(Game game, Move move) {
        // If the move captures a piece and the number of moves played so far is less than numProtectedMoves, disallow it
        if (move.getCaptured() != null && game.getMovesPlayed() < numProtectedMoves) {
            return false;
        }
        return true;
    }

    @Override
    public String getDescription() {
        return "Capturing piece in the first " + this.numProtectedMoves + " moves are not allowed";
    }
}
```

**Explanation:**  
- `move.getCaptured()` checks if the move captures a piece (returns non-null if yes).  
- `game.getMovesPlayed()` returns the number of moves played so far.  
- If the move is a capture and the number of moves played is less than the protected number, the move is invalid. Otherwise, it is valid.  

Please verify and adjust method names according to your actual `Game` and `Move` interfaces if needed.

```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;

/**
 * Global rule that requires the source and destination should be inside the board boundary.
 */
public class OutOfBoundaryRule implements Rule {
	@Override
	public boolean validate(Game game, Move move) {
		int boardWidth = game.getBoardWidth();
		int boardHeight = game.getBoardHeight();

		int sourceX = move.getSourceX();
		int sourceY = move.getSourceY();
		int destX = move.getDestX();
		int destY = move.getDestY();

		boolean sourceInBounds = sourceX >= 0 && sourceX < boardWidth && sourceY >= 0 && sourceY < boardHeight;
		boolean destInBounds = destX >= 0 && destX < boardWidth && destY >= 0 && destY < boardHeight;

		return sourceInBounds && destInBounds;
	}

	@Override
	public String getDescription() {
		return "place is out of boundary of gameboard";
	}
}
```

This implementation assumes that the `Game` interface provides `getBoardWidth()` and `getBoardHeight()` methods and that `Move` provides `getSourceX()`, `getSourceY()`, `getDestX()`, and `getDestY()` methods to access the coordinates. The method returns `true` only if both source and destination are within the board boundaries.

Response Text:---
The compilation errors indicate that the methods `getBoardWidth()`, `getBoardHeight()` in `Game` and `getSourceX()`, `getSourceY()`, `getDestX()`, `getDestY()` in `Move` do not exist. You need to use the correct methods or accessors provided by those interfaces/classes to get the board dimensions and move coordinates.

Typically, board dimensions might be accessed via a method like `getBoard()` returning a board object, or directly via `getWidth()` and `getHeight()` methods. Similarly, `Move` might provide source and destination positions as objects or arrays, or via different method names.

Assuming the `Game` interface provides a method `getBoard()` returning a board object with `getWidth()` and `getHeight()`, and `Move` provides `getSource()` and `getDestination()` returning position objects with `getX()` and `getY()`, the code should be adapted accordingly.

Here is a corrected complete class assuming these typical method names:

```java
package assignment.piece;

import assignment.protocol.Game;
import assignment.protocol.Move;
import assignment.protocol.Position;

/**
 * Global rule that requires the source and destination should be inside the board boundary.
 */
public class OutOfBoundaryRule implements Rule {
	@Override
	public boolean validate(Game game, Move move) {
		int boardWidth = game.getBoard().getWidth();
		int boardHeight = game.getBoard().getHeight();

		Position source = move.getSource();
		Position dest = move.getDestination();

		int sourceX = source.getX();
		int sourceY = source.getY();
		int destX = dest.getX();
		int destY = dest.getY();

		boolean sourceInBounds = sourceX >= 0 && sourceX < boardWidth && sourceY >= 0 && sourceY < boardHeight;
		boolean destInBounds = destX >= 0 && destX < boardWidth && destY >= 0 && destY < boardHeight;

		return sourceInBounds && destInBounds;
	}

	@Override
	public String getDescription() {
		return "place is out of boundary of gameboard";
	}
}
```

This assumes the following:
- `Game` has a method `getBoard()` returning an object with `getWidth()` and `getHeight()`.
- `Move` has methods `getSource()` and `getDestination()` returning `Position` objects.
- `Position` has methods `getX()` and `getY()`.

If your actual interfaces differ, adjust the method calls accordingly.
